awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides partial support for US-based participants in the international conference "Hyperplane Arrangements and Singularities" to be held at the University of Tokyo (in Tokyo, Japan), during the period December 2-6, 2019. The conference will be research-oriented, intended to disseminate recent developments, but it will also include introductory lectures at a level accessible to graduate students. Additionally, there will be discussion sessions, so as to better strengthen connections among the various research groups represented and to provide accessibility for junior researchers and graduate students. 

The conference will focus around recent developments in the study of hyperplane arrangements and singular spaces, with applications to algebraic and geometric topology, algebraic geometry, group theory, and combinatorics. The topics to be discussed will include, but will not be limited to, the following areas, all of which have seen important new developments in the past several years: Topology and geometry of hyperplane arrangements, Milnor fibrations, Cohomology jump loci, Arrangements of smooth submanifolds, Geometry and topology of non-isolated singularities, Perverse sheaves, and mixed Hodge modules. These topics intersect a broad range of research endeavors in fields ranging from pure mathematics to more applied areas, and thus conference participants will reflect a broad cross-section of mathematical disciplines. An important objective of the conference is to promote dissemination of information and cross-fertilization between hyperplane arrangements, singularity theory, and related fields. By sharing their respective techniques and perspectives, participants are expected to form new collaborations and make advances at the meeting points of those fields. More details about the conference are available at: https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/hyper-jarcs/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary purpose of this project was to introduce junior researchers to fast-developing research areas in Hyperplane Arrangements and Singularity Theory, and their interactions with other areas of mathematics. This was done through the organization of a major international conference at the University of Tokyo, Japan, several follow-up online workshops, and an in-person conference at Northeastern University in Boston.

The "Hyperplane Arrangements and Singularities" conference, held in Tokyo in December 2919, focused on recent developments in the study of hyperplane arrangements and singular spaces, with applications to algebraic and geometric topology, algebraic geometry, group theory, and combinatorics. The meeting brought together active contributors in these fields working in the United States, and allowed them to interact with leading experts, postdocs, and graduate students from Asia, Australia, Europe, and the Americas. Thanks to the NSF support, a substantial contingent of US participants (many of them junior) was represented at the conference, which attracted some 70-80 participants in all. The meeting featured over 30 high-quality talks by world experts and strong junior researchers. A well-attended poster session enhanced the opportunities for junior researchers and graduate students to present their current work. Several social events arranged by the local organizers encouraged the sharing of ideas and perspectives regarding the themes of the meeting. Many of the participants, including all those coming from the US, expressed their appreciation for the opportunity to attend this conference, exchange ideas and perspectives on various research and educational endeavors, and either establish or renew contacts. The conference was of special benefit to early-career US participants, who benefitted from the exposure and from seeing a wider panorama of ideas and research directions fitting their areas of research.

The conference generated a considerable amount of buzz, leading to strong interest and substantial participation in a series of three online workshops titled "Arrangements at Home" in the summer of 2020 and in the conference on "Compactifications, Configurations, and Cohomology", held in-person at Northeastern University in October 2021 with support from the NSF grant.

A Special Issue of the journal Topology and its Applications collects selected articles based on presentations delivered at the Hyperplane Arrangements and Singularities conference. The proceedings, edited by conference organizers, includes contributions from most of the speakers and some of their collaborators. The papers cover a wide range of topics, ranging from singularity theory and hyperplane arrangements to algebraic and geometric topology, algebraic geometry, and combinatorics.
